Generally no room for growth.

Everyone knows there’s no pay in the psych field, and despite this company’s 17 some-odd Vice President’s last time I checked, they lean heavily on that being an accepted fact and don’t try to prioritize livable wages for their staff in the lower branches.

It seemed like it was a solid company when I started the beginning my 4 year stint there and by the end it was clear the higher ups were prioritizing external endeavors than finding ways to ensure their staff felt valued and were motivated to continue doing stellar work. 

When I’ve heard others bring up their concerns they get shut down and the conversation is redirected to all the awesome things that are happening (very possibly with the help of the people being ignored).

Raises were infrequent, I had one in 4 years and it was abysmal. I heard there was another after I left that was much much more respectful, and then I think I heard health insurance was raised significantly.

pros: Riverside has an unbelievable upper management team. I have been recognized and rewarded for the way this program has grown and I am vert grateful for those who advocated for my program to make it was it is today. Riverside is amazing and flexible and care about your well being. They understand that your personal life comes first and that mental health is too important to ignore.

pros: Riverside tries to treat their employees like people, most of the time. They hardly ever fire anybody, so your job security blanket is good. That's good and bad, because they hold on to some really terrible people that have no people skills and no right to be in a field in which they are supposed to be supporting people. PTO is good, but requesting time off varies from site to site, and even by role (I've worked in a couple different positions in the past 2 and a half years). This is a high burnout field, but from what I hear from my colleagues, Riverside is by far better than any surrounding mental health companies (besides working for the state or a hospital).
cons: BURNOUT. Direct care is usually unrewarding and makes you distrust people and their intentions. Oftentimes I feel manipulated by clients. Thankfully, most of my coworkers are great, but there have definitely been some cases of people who have been really difficult to work with (but you could get that at any job with any company).

pros: There is a great group of dedicated clinicians and paraprofessionals that provide high quality services to individuals in need of MH services.

There is a lack of adequate supervision available for clinical staff. There is very little room for advancement and the pay is very low for the work that is required.

review_title: a company that cares for clients
pros: A great place to get started in the mental health field. Caring for clients doesn't end at the ground floor, as management (at least middle management) is there to provide additional support where they can for clients and staff. The pay is good compared to other introductory work in the field, and it is easy to pick up additional shifts for overtime if you want to. If you want to help people and work for a company that truly aims for that goal too, this is the place.
cons:
You will need to come in for snow storms with no additional incentive to do so beyond regular pay and avoiding being scolded for calling out. Drive safe.
There is potential for burn out in the lower level staffing positions as is common in this field, but the scheduling for shifts certainly plays into this: daytime residential staff have consistent schedules week to week, but the hours vary day to day. This can wear one down over time with the effect it has on sleep schedules and throw off the work to life balance a bit.

pros:
- A unique and rewarding experience providing valuable therapeutic support to young people and their families 
- Great exposure to a wide variety of careers in mental health and other helping professions. You will work with and learn from a multi-disciplinary team of providers in each of your client's lives (family therapists, psychiatrists, school administrators, department of mental health case workers, outpatient therapists, etc)
- Coworkers within the program are all very nice, helpful and interesting individuals committed to the work; you will learn a lot from them and be inspired by them too!
- Managers provide many opportunities for professional learning opportunities and growth. If you want to learn how to run staff training, the opportunity is there. Want to get better at doing group therapy? You can do that too. Want to get paid to teach guitar, go hiking, make some art, ride horses, visit animal shelters, go to the beach or whatever else you want to do? Ask for a client that has those interests and you will probably get one. Though you won't get rich (financially) doing this job, management does their best to make your job rewarding in other ways. 
- Your individual strengths are valued. You are treated with dignity and your safety is prioritized. Your supervisors actually care about you and your well-being.
- Flexible hours: totally possible to balance with a class or two if you want to go back to school part-time (full time school would be tough)
- Many opportunities to earn incentive bonus pay. If you are strategic and good at managing your time, you can easily earn a salary 20-30% above your base pay by regularly exceeding your productivity requirement (read: don't be scared away by the base salary! it is not that hard to earn more and beats getting a second job).
cons:
- You will spend a lot of time completing tedious paperwork for insurance purposes and it may sometimes feel like that drains your energy to do the actual therapeutic work 
- The pay could be better
- If you hate driving, this is not the job for you

pros: Peers are great to work with and the reason to come to work. Benefits are fair with the exception of no annual review, low salary, no 403b match.
